net.cloud.gfx.elements.decorator

Class FramedElement

  • java.lang.Object
    • net.cloud.gfx.elements.decorator.AbstractDecoratorElement
      • net.cloud.gfx.elements.decorator.FramedElement
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    DecoratorElement, Element, Focusable

    public class FramedElement
extends AbstractDecoratorElement
    An element decorated (literally) with a border and title around it. In other words, it creates a frame around an existing element. The frame does not come with movement build into it, but can be achieved by wrapping this decorator further in a DraggableElement. In the top right of the frame, there may be buttons. These may be dynamically specified, so there can be none or several. There are pre-canned buttons to choose from that will perform a default action or further a specified action.
    See Also:
    FrameButton, FrameButtonAction

        A map of the buttons in the frame. May be none. Each is mapped to the graphical button and an action

        The background within the top. Fits same size as it, with the border on top.

        Border framing the top. Aligned to width of wrapped element.

      • rightBorder

        Border framing the right. Stretched to fit up to the top and bottom, but not over

        private java.awt.image.BufferedImage bottomBorder
        Border framing the bottom. Aligned to width of wrapped element.

      • leftBorder

        private java.awt.image.BufferedImage leftBorder
        Border framing the left. Stretched to fit up to the top and bottom, but not over

    • Constructor Detail

      • FramedElement

        public FramedElement(java.lang.String title,
                     Element toDecorate,
                     FrameButton... buttons)
        Create a new FramedElement by wrapping the frame around an existing element. There will always be the title showing. By default, there will be no buttons, though. The default frame images will be used and scaled to the correct size. The scaling will not happen if the element is resized through the element rather than through the decorator, post-creation. Buttons may also be specified now, or later through one of the addFrameButton() methods. If added here, they will behave as if done via addFrameButton(buttonType)
        Parameters:
        title - The title showing in the top left of the frame
        toDecorate - The element to add a frame to
        buttons - An optional list of buttons to include in the frame. Ordered right to left

        public Element topElementAtPoint(java.awt.Point point)
                          throws IteratorException
        Behaves like the super class in that if the top element is the wrapped element, it will be treated as 'this' However this element will also be the top at the point if the point is over the frame border anywhere

        See addFrameButton(FrameButton, int, BiConsumer)

        buttonSprite - The sprite ID of the button

      • addFrameButton

        public void addFrameButton(FrameButton buttonType,
                           int buttonSprite,
                           java.util.function.BiConsumer<FramedElement,AbstractButton> action)
        Add a button to this frame. It will be positioned to the left of any existing buttons, or in the top right of the frame if there are no other buttons. The type of the button defines, well, what kind it is. Frames really only need a limited number of buttons, so typing them allows for easier use. If a button of the same type already exists, then it will be overwritten. The sprite is the ID of the image in the Button set. Its size will not be scaled, so it should fit within the top border of the frame. The action is a method that will be called when the button is pressed. It is provided both this FramedElement instance and the Button instance that was pressed.
        Parameters:
        buttonType - The type of button, so defaults are available
        buttonSprite - The sprite ID of the button
        action - An action to perform when the button is pressed

      • removeFrameButton

        public void removeFrameButton(FrameButton buttonType)
        Removes a button from the frame, clean and simple. Will not reposition the remaining buttons, since this is likely border scenario. (Create the frame only with the desired buttons). If the button doesn't exist, nothing will happen
        Parameters:
        buttonType - The type of the button to remove

      • getTitleBounds

        public java.awt.Rectangle getTitleBounds()
        Get the bounding rectangle of just the top border, the part that contains the title information. This is useful for setting the restrictions on where dragging may occur, for example.
        Returns:
        A bounding rectangle on the top border, relative to within this element

        public void setFrameSpriteGroup(int firstID)
        Sets the border images to use for this frame. They are scaled to the correct size.
        Parameters:

      • setBgSprite

        public void setBgSprite(SpriteSet set,
                        int ID)
        Sets the background sprite that will be a background for the title border. It is set to the same size as the top border, so if setting both frame sprites and this, you should set the frame sprites first.
        Parameters:
        set - The SpriteSet the background is in
        ID - The sprite ID of the background image
